Use the table of values for the functions \(p(x)\) and \(q(x)\) below to complete the tables for the composite functions defined in parts (a) and (b): \par \begin{center}
\par\smallskip\begin{center}\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline
\(x\) &0 &1 &2 &3 &4 &5 \\ \hline
\(p(x)\) &5 &4 &3 &0 &1 &2 \\ \hline
\(q(x)\) &5 &3 &1 &2 &4 &0 \\ \hline
\end {tabular}\end{center}\par\smallskip
\end{center} \par (a) Complete the table of values for the composite function \(r(x) = p( q(x) )\) at \(x = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5\) \leavevmode\\\relax \begin{center}
\par\smallskip\begin{center}\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline
\(x\) &0 &1 &2 &3 &4 &5 \\ \hline
\(r(x)\) &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} \\ \hline
\end {tabular}\end{center}\par\smallskip
\end{center}
\par (b) Complete the table of values for the composite function \(s(x) = q( p(x) )\) at \(x = 0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5\). \leavevmode\\\relax \begin{center}
\par\smallskip\begin{center}\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|c|c|} \hline
\(x\) &0 &1 &2 &3 &4 &5 \\ \hline
\(s(x)\) &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} &\mbox{\parbox[t]{3ex}{\hrulefill}} \\ \hline
\end {tabular}\end{center}\par\smallskip
\end{center} \leavevmode\\\relax
\par \par {\bf Solution: }\par {\bf SOLUTION } \par (a) To construct a table of values for \(r\), we must evaluate \(r(0)\), \(r(1) , \ldots , r(5)\). Starting with \(r(0)\), we have \(r(0) = p(q(0))\). We have \(r(0) = p(q(0)) = p(5)\) because \(q(0)=5\). Using the table given in the problem, we thus have \(r(0) = p(5) = 2\). \par We can repeat this process for \(r(1)=p(q(1))=p(3)=0\). Similarly, \[\begin{aligned} r(2)&=p(q(2))=p(1)=4 \\ r(3)&=p(q(3))=p(2)=3 \\ r(4)&=p(q(4))=p(4)=1 \\ r(5)&=p(q(5))=p(0)=5 \end{aligned}\] \par
(b) To construct a table of values for \(s\), we perform the same method as in part (a), in the opposite order of composition. We have \(s(0)=q(5)\) because \(p(0)=5\). Using the table given, we have \(s(0) = 0\). \par We can repeat this process for \(s(1)=q(p(1))=q(4)=4\). Similarly, \[\begin{aligned} s(2)&=q(p(2))=q(3)=2 \\ s(3)&=q(p(3))=q(0)=5\\ s(4)&=q(p(4))=q(1)=3\\ s(5)&=q(p(5))=q(2)=1 \end{aligned}\]
\par
